Award.AwardTitle: International Workshop on Computational Network Biology: Modeling, Analysis, and Control (CNB-MAC 2015)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The 2nd Workshop on Computational Network Biology: Modeling, Analysis, and Control (CNB-MAC 2015) will be held in conjunction with the 6th ACM International Conference on Bioinformatics, Computational Biology and Health Informatics (ACM-BCB 2015), which will be a continuation of the first CNB-MAC workshop, hosted by ACM-BCB 2014. The workshop will attract researchers from multiple disciplines of engineering, computer science, statistics, biology, and chemistry. The partnership with ACM-BCB 2015 will help increase the awareness of the importance of rigorous mathematical modeling for accurate and reproducible results on deriving biology knowledge in computational biology in the big data era. CNB-MAC 2015 will offer both a keynote presentation and a tutorial along this direction to provide future research directions for participating graduate students and post-doctoral researchers. One of the important missions of the workshop is to foster education and development of the next-generation scientists, especially women and minority, in computational network biology. CNB-MAC 2015 will provide travel awards to encourage graduate students to participate and submit papers. Specifically, 20-30% of the awards will be allocated to encourage women and minority students.

Next generation high-throughput profiling technologies have enabled more systematic and comprehensive studies of living systems. Network models play crucial roles in understanding the complex interactions that govern biological systems, and their interactions with external environment. The main emphasis of CNB-MAC 2015 will be on rigorous mathematical or computational approaches in studying biological networks, analyzing large-scale OMICS data, and investigating mathematical models for human-microbiome-environment interactions. Complementary to the focus on informatics tools and learning algorithms for big data in ACM-BCB 2015 and other workshops, CNB-MAC 2015 aims to provide a synergistic scientific forum for presenting recent advances in computational network biology that involve modeling, analysis, and control of biological systems under different conditions, and systematic analysis of large-scale OMICS data.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2nd Workshop on Computational Network Biology: Modeling, Analysis, and Control (CNB-MAC 2015, http://www.ece.tamu.edu/~bjyoon/CNB-MAC-2015/) was held on September 9th, 2015, in Atlanta, GA, in conjunction with the 6th ACM International Conference on Bioinformatics, Computational Biology and Health Informatics (ACM-BCB 2015: http://acm-bcb.bme.gatech.edu/2015/). The workshop provided a scientific forum for computer scientists, engineers, and biologists who work in the field of computational network biology to share recent research findings, identify new challenges, and explore potential areas for collaboration. The main emphasis of the workshop was on rigorous mathematical or computational approaches in studying biological networks, analyzing large-scale OMICS data, and investigating mathematical models for effective analysis of human-microbiome-environment interactions by providing keynote presentations, highlights presentations, regular research oral and poster presentations.

Based on the review comments for 15 submissions, we selected 2 submissions for the regular research oral presentations, 5 for highlighs, and 6 for poster presentations. In addition, we invited Dr. Shuzhao Li from Emory University for the keynote presentation. In conjunction with ACM-BCB 2015, we also had a tutorial for biological network analysis by one of the organizers, Dr. Xiaoning Qian. The workshop was relatively small yet vibrant and provided an excellent venue for young researchers working in computational network biology to share ideas and get involved in deep scholarly discussions, thereby ultimately contribute to the advancement of the field of computational network biology. The full-day workshop always had more than 30 people in the audience and all the presentations were followed with deep discussions on relevant topics. In the session of Closing Remarks, the participants of the workshop commented that they really enjoyed the workshop on both the depth and breadth of the covered topics and hoped that the workshop will continue with the same style next year. 

This project provided travel support for graduate students to attend the workshop to promote the participation of graduate students as well postdoctoral researchers and help foster education and development of the next-generation scientists, especially women and minority, in computational network biology. The requested travel support allowed to promote the participation of graduate students in this highly multi-disciplinary research field in the workshop, with efforts to especially encourage female and minority students to contribute to the field. From nine applicants, we selected seven graduate students from different universities to grant them the travel support: 

1. Meltem Apaydin (Texas A&M University, female);

2. Ali Floroughipour (Ohio State University);

3. Lei Huang (Drexel University);

4. Hyundoo Jeong (Texas A&M University);

5. Jimmy Mansuck Kim (Texas A&M University);

6. Qingming Tang (Toyota Technological Institute at Chicago);

7. Wei Zhang (University of Minnesota).

Participation in the workshop will have the following important benefits for these graduate students:

  • Attending keynote, tutorial, and highlights lectures and talks can expose them with firsthand knowledge on frontier research that can have a significant impact on their own research outcomes.
